etymology.description: 官(官) (guān, "official") + 二(二) (èr, "two; second") + 代(代) (dài, "generation")
etymology.interpretation: The term 官二代 (guān’èrdài) refers to the children of government officials. '二代' (èrdài, "second generation") is often used in Chinese to denote the children or descendants of a certain group, and 官(官) (guān, "official") specifies that these are the offspring of people in official positions. The phrase carries connotations of privilege and inherited status in contemporary China.

examples.chinese: 官二代在社会中备受关注(官二代在社會中備受關注)，他们享有许多优于普通人的机会(他們享有許多優於普通人的機會)。
examples.pinyin: Guān’èrdài zài shèhuì zhōng bèishòu guānzhù, tāmen xiǎngyǒu xǔduō yōuyú pǔtōng rén de jīhuì.
examples.english: Children of officials receive considerable attention in society, and they enjoy many opportunities superior to those of ordinary people.

examples.chinese: 有些官二代不愿背负家族的期望(有些官二代不願背負家族的期望)。
examples.pinyin: Yǒuxiē guān’èrdài bù yuàn bèifù jiāzú de qīwàng.
examples.english: Some children of officials are reluctant to bear their family's expectations.
